comments.body: Call `Write-VerboseServiceInfoToConsole $NPD_SERVICE` here?
Would it be better to just assume the path is hard codes or pass the config through kubeenv?

I guess we can do so, but I feel that assuming the config location never changes isn't perfect especially with containerd. unlike docker, where its installed package always keep the binaries in a well-known path, containerd is shipped as tar and can be extracted anywhere. This makes it a bit safer, so we don't re-register service as we guarantee the extracted config location is what being used. If non is found, then it'll be the default path hardcoded by containerd.
Why was this changed to Restart-Service?

Because it was assuming that the runtime is always installed fresh through the script, now the service could already be existing and running, so we'll need to have a restart after updating its config.

Another thought: to ensure these changes take effect, it might be a good idea to restart the Windows Defender service.

Here's what I see when examining the Windows services:
```
PS C:\Windows\system32> get-service | Where-Object 'DisplayName' -like "*efender*"

Status   Name               DisplayName
------   ----               -----------
Running  mpssvc             Windows Defender Firewall
Stopped  Sense              Windows Defender Advanced Threat Pr...
Running  WdNisSvc           Windows Defender Antivirus Network ...
Running  WinDefend          Windows Defender Antivirus Service
```

WinDefend looks like the relevant service. Can you try adding this command here too?:

```
Restart-Service WinDefend
```

Looked into this a bit. If you go to `services.msc` the `WinDefend` service has all the service control options grayed out. This is probably intentional due to the criticality of the service itself. Instead I'd recommend just dumping out the Windows Defender prefs via `Get-MpPreference`

Also given that the command does not reveal itself I'd recommend adding a `Log-Output`? command to ensure folks can search it.

comments.body:
gsutil ls -l gs://gke-release/cni-plugins/v0.8.5-gke*

currently .sha512 is not available, only .sha1
is there a script to generate the sha1 files? or manually did it? i'll generate sha512 files.
sha1 files are there, sha512 is missing currently
i meant how those sha1 files are created. via a script or a command? i don't have permission to `gsutil cp` to the bucket.

From https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/e99dbbde62015c15b516cdf39edb8d32fcd71729/cluster/gce/config-common.sh#L143, the bucket is `k8s-artifacts-cni`.

`gsutil ls -l gs://k8s-artifacts-cni/release/v0.8.7/cni-plugins-windows*`

shows that the sha512 files are present. I'm not sure why the `gke-release` bucket is different, but for this PR this change looks good.
replied in bug

Would there ever be a reason not to use --hostname-override?

We could make the use of this flag conditional based on whether or not some key is set in the kube-env, but not sure if that level of control is needed.
We can check if the hostname and instance name are different and apply the flag when they are different only. Do you feel this will be better?

I assume that it wouldn't make a difference if we apply the flag when the hostname and instance name are the same.

I still have the question, would there ever be a reason not to use --hostname-override? If the answer is no, that's fine and we can leave this as is.

If we can make all GKE generated name to be <= 15 characters then we won't need to override the hostname. This change will not be trivial and have user impact as users are already familiar with today's naming convention. So it is not something we can complete very soon.  I can't think out a reason to not use --hostname-override for now.
With fluent-bit and flb-exporter now, should we try to remove all this extra restart logic that we needed for the unreliable Stackdriver agent?
I see the same behavior with fluentbit also. The process needed to be killed. Iam sure they will fix it at some point but for now it is the case.
Ok, thanks for checking.

comments.body:
Can you separate out the part of the installation that downloads the files and puts them into the right directories from the part of the installation that configures the services using `sc.exe`, and put them into two different functions?

This will make it easier to make sure we don't mess up when we've already done the first part on our preloaded node images. We take this approach elsewhere in this script for configuring the container runtime, CNI, etc.

Install-LoggingAgent - Download, install
Configure-LoggingAgent - Configure the agent
Restart-LogginAgent - Restart the agent after configuration


Did you want to split Install-LoggingAgent into:
- Download-LoggingAgent
- Install-LoggingAgentService

And conditionally call them from Install-LoggingAgent ?
Download and install can probably be one step/function. Then we'll skip that entire function if the files are already present, and just configure + restart.
Oh wait, I see what you're saying. Sure, one function to download and place the files and a second function to install/configure the service itself would be great.
ack

@jeremyje has a PR out to do this for Stackdriver; we should decide which values make sense to use here.

@jeremyje that PR might be obsolete now that we have this one.

comments.body:
If a failure occurs, do you know what happens to the log file that the agent writes to? When the agent restarts will the log messages that would contain information about the failure be preserved, or will the agent clear the old logs?

If the latter, it would be helpful to see if we can figure out a way to preserve the failure logs.

I booted up a Windows and ran `taskkill /F /IM ruby.exe`.

You can see this in the logs StackDriver logs:
```
The Stackdriver Logging service terminated unexpectedly.  It has done this 1 time(s).  The following corrective action will be taken in 1000 milliseconds: Restart the service.

The Stackdriver Logging service entered the running state.
```

Also logs are emitted to Stackdriver so if the exporter crashes at some point it's possible that we lose some logs but we at least know when that happened.

Thanks for checking that. There's also a log file at `C:\programfilesx86\stackdriver\fluentd.log`, or something like that (pulled the path from an old chat). Can you check that file too? 

I'm not sure if fluentd is configured to send its own log file to Stackdriver logging - if it is, cool. If not, it would be nice if the file continues to get appended to after the restart, rather than overwritten.

The logs are preserved.
`type 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Stackdriver\LoggingAgent\fluentd.log'`

it is based on a code sample about text parsing in powershell. the yaml here is just 'key:value' pairs, we don't really need a full-blown yaml parser, IMO. also the kube env is provided by the control plane, e2e tests should be able to catch the corner cases before they hit production.

this powershell module is used soley by GCE/GKE, please keep using the gs bucket (gs://gke-release/cni-plugins/v0.8.5-gke.0/) that our release team maintains.

@yliaog -- Is there a reason we'd want the Windows tarballs to diverge from the ones provided by the CNI plugins maintainers & Kubernetes community?

The goal here is to provide everything from a single bucket, which has shared control between the CNI maintainers and Kubernetes Release Engineering.

Are there concerns on the Windows side that make this vary from the artifacts we're retrieving on Linux side (which also get used for the GCE/GKE tests)?

(That is to say, I think all of these artifacts should come from the same place and I don't think this PR should be held.)

Done.
Why do we need to set this in the profile?

Import-Module will only work for the current powershell session. When later Get-GcePdName is executed in a different session, it will not work. Setting to this profile will make all users and all sessions can access the command
Not part of this PR. But this seems super hacky/brittle. Can discuss offline.
We have https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/74674 open to track the real fix, then we'll be able to remove this.

Yes, it always return `The operation completed successfully.`
